chapter.title: Development Environment Setup
chapter.para: In order to start developing for the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; platform, one needs to setup a specific development environment, with source code as well as configuration files and utilities. In this chapter, we will describe how to create such an environment.

section.title: Requirement: a Test Server
section.para: The &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; source code has been modified so that multiple instances of the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; software can run on the same physical machine. The goal here is to allow each &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; developer to have his/her own source tree available for modification and testing and avoid any interference with other developers.

When developing for &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME;, it is strongly advised to test your code on a different machine than the production server. Even if you use a different source tree and a different database, there are always risks that you might do something wrong that will impact your production server. So you should setup a dedicated machine for all your code development. Ideally, this machine should be identical to the production server, or at least it should have exactly the same operating system (same distribution, same version) and the same version of the tools (CVS, Apache, PHP, MySQL, etc.).

For simplification, we will describe the process of setting up development environments that all share the same database server, and where specific features like project web servers, documentation, user accounts, releases, cron jobs and CVS repositories are also common to all environments. Using separate resources is possible but requires a lot more efforts.

section.title: Creating a Development Environment
section.para: Initially, you need to create a 'test_server' directory in your home directory, where you will install all necessary resources to develop, configure, and run &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME;. You may setup files as you wish, but here, we provide a guideline that will simplify things. So first, you should create the following subdirectories:
section.programlisting: bin etc etc/codendi etc/httpd etc/httpd/conf httpd sfcache var var/log var/log/httpd var/run
section.para: Then make links for your apache server
section.programlisting: cd etc/httpd ln -s /usr/lib/apache modules ln -s ../../var/log/httpd logs

section.title: Editing Configuration Files
section.para: Now, your directory contains the same configuration files as the test server. You need to customize them for your specific environment.

section.para: You need to edit etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf for your test server. Again, here are some guidelines, but beware that some parameters may be different in your installation. listitem.para: ServerRoot: point to your test_server/etc/httpd directory

Port and Listen directives: use unique numbers. If your running a secure server (https) you need to specify two 'Listen' directives and change the appropriate settings.
DocumentRoot: point to test_server/httpd/src/www. Also update the corresponding 'Directory' directive.
ScriptAlias: point to test_server/httpd/cgi-bin. Also update the corresponding 'Directory' directive.
All Log directives: point to var/log/httpd if they point to absolute paths

section.title: Creating a Development Environment on Another Machine
section.para: Sometimes, it might not be convenient to develop on the test server itself, e.g. when you cannot directly edit source files (remote file system). In this case you can also setup a development environment on another machine (e.g. on your own desktop if it is a Linux Box). Please note, however, that you have to be careful with some aspects:

listitem.para: You might have to install and setup your own versions of PHP, Apache and MySQL (you can also use the MySQL server located on the test server). This is not described in this document.

If your setup is not exactly the same as the production server (Linux, PHP or Apache versions), you will probably need to re-test your code on the test server before committing your changes or updating the production server.

section.title: Installing the Source Code
section.para: All &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; source files (PHP, Perl and shell scripts) are located in the '/home/httpd' directory, or '~user/testserver/httpd' on your development environment. In order to install the source code, you should 'cd' in this directory, and checkout the sources there. We assume that you have access to a SVN server containing the source code. Otherwise, you can also simply copy the source code located in /home/httpd.
In order to checkout the source code of the CX_2_0_SUP branch, you may use the following command:
section.programlisting: cvs -d:pserver:user_name@cvs.codendi.servername.com:/cvsroot/codendi checkout\ -r CX_2_0_SUP SF cgi-bin codendi_tools documentation site-content
section.para: ...where user_name is the login name, and servername.com is the name of the server hosting the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; SVN repository.
This will install the latest version of the given branch in your directory.

section.title: Running &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME;
section.para: Now you may run the server: since all code is written in interpreted languages, there is no compilation step.

Provided that the MySQL database server is running (it should be launched at startup time), you only need to run the HTTP server in order to start &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME;. So go back to 'test_server/bin' and run the 'start_Codendi' script.
Now, in a browser window, type the server URL (don't forget the port number)... et voila!
